title: Gutsy Strathpeffer teenager gets one step closer to Paralympics
story: A ROSS-SHIRE teenager whose determination to overcome disability and devastating setbacks has inspired thousands of people is a huge step closer to realising his dream of cycling for Great Britain.Despite being born with two club feet and no calf muscle in his right leg, Fin Graham has never wavered in his determination to represent his nation at the  Tokyo Paralympics.To have any chance of doing that, he needed to secure a coveted full-time training place with Team GB at state-of-the-art facilities in Manchester.The ambitious goal looked doubtful after he was hit out of the blue by lupus, a disease which sees the bodyrsquos immune system attack its own tissues and organs.But remarkably, the gutsy -year-old has overcome the odds to secure a slot ndash and only last weekend again proved his worth by striking silver at a Track Cycling World Cup event, notching a personal best in front of a raucous home crowd.This week, he ed to his old school, Dingwall Academy, to share his story with pupils and encourage them to follow their dreams no matter the challenges.Earlier this year, the Ross-shire Journal highlighted a crowdfunding drive he launched to help meet mounting travel and training costs. Incredibly, the pound target was smashed within days, hundreds of complete strangers inspired by his determination amongst the backers.Speaking to the Ross-shire Journal this week, he said: "Since getting access to the best facilities and coaches, my performance has improved and Im getting personal bests. Cycling in front of a home crowd in London was just so much fun ndash the noise was ridiculous and I just didnt want to come off the track."He powered through the km four-lap race in m s, pipped by just a fraction of a second by the reigning world champion.Fin, who needs a leg brace to race, was quick to thank those who have shown faith in him, not least parents Dee and Drew who have backed his dream from the start and driven him thousands of miles around the country to compete. "Without them, none of this would have happened," he said. "They were able to come down to London to watch, which was very special."After being invited to talk to pupils at his former school, Fin said he shared his highs and lows and spoke of the importance of setting a target ndash even amidst setbacks such as his illness.A spokesman at Dingwall Academy said: "Effort, resilience, embracing challenge, listening to feedback, never giving up and learning from failures were all great messages."His mum Dee, a childrens nurse, earlier told the Journal: "We have no idea what the future holds. But what I have learned from Fin is to take each day at a time. Seize the moment."Thursday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Hope fades of swift fix for Stromeferry bypass
story: LONG-running problems on the Stromeferry bypass look set to be left to Highland Council to solve ndash at least in the short term.The area is notorious for frequent rock falls and landslips that block the bypass leading to a ersion of more than  miles. And there have been hopes that the Scottish Government might offer financial support for a permanent fix.Council leader Margaret Davison met transport minister Michael Matheson at the end of November but the only outcome was advice to apply for Scottish Futures Trust funding.Councillor Davidson was asked about the meeting by Derek MacLeod, the local ward member, to find outany progress had been made at the meeting.She explained: ldquoThe cabinet secretary advised that the council should talk with Scottish Futures Trust with regard to potential funding options.ldquoYour other comment was about the strategic transport review ndash that is not due until  as far as I know and he spoke about Stromeferry being part of that reviewwe wanted to put it forward.She said: ldquoWe will be continuing to prepare, we have no option ndash we have a duty to the people that use that road daily.Cllr Macleod is growing weary of the to-and-fro between council and government.He said: ldquoOn the question of whether the Scottish Government recognises their responsibilities under the RoadsAct  to regularly review the Strategic Roads Network there was no answer.ldquoThe long-awaited response to the STAG appraisal... will probably repeat the assertion that as a local authority road [itrsquos] not a problem for Scottish ministers or Transport Scotland.Thursday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Jobs on the line claim over Dingwall parking changes
story: BUSINESSES in Ross-shire are set to step up opposition to the introduction of car parking charges following grim warnings of plunging profits and job losses in Angus just weeks after a charging regime was introduced there.Dingwall and Seaforth councillor Graham Mackenzie said images of empty car parks in towns in Angus since charges were introduced to off-street facilities there last month should give pause for thought here.Cllr Mackenzie said: ldquoIt seems to have had a really detrimental impact. I would suggest it is worth listening to what people in Angus have to say. My message would be: lsquoItrsquos not too late to stop thisrsquo. There has still been no consultation whatsoever. There seems to be desire for a one-size fits all approach but there lsquos a reason parking charges werenrsquot introduced in some towns which are not major tourist destinations.Fellow ward councillor Margaret Paterson told the Ross-shire Journal: ldquoI am  per cent that imposing parking charges would without a doubt damage our lovely High Street and I will not stand by and let that happen.Montrose-based Michelle Ingram of Angus Business and Retailers Association said the business impact had been immediate and ldquovery negative. She said: ldquoMy business is down  per cent like for like in November. Some people report being down  per cent. It has killed browsing and there is a real drop in footfall.Highland Council is looking at rolling out charges to a number of areas which enjoy free parking at present. The council, seeking to balance its books, has said some of the cash raised will be spent locally.What do you think  Email newsdesk@spp-groupThursday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Kishorn dry dock visits are a big success
story: THE colossal dry dock at Kishorn Port echoed to the sounds of dozens of Wester Ross school children when they got to explore it first-hand.More than  youngsters and teachers from Plockton High School and the primaries in Lochcarron and Applecross were given a guided tour of the facilities during two open days.The pupils received an interesting presentation from the portrsquos director Simon Russell detailing the history of the site and the future hopes and plans for the facilities. This was then followed by a tour of the yard and dry dock by fellow director Alasdair Ferguson. Mr Russell said: ldquoThe level of interest and the insightful questions were most rewarding. And the schools were not the only locals to get a close-up view of the dock. Three dozen residents and community figures also got to enjoy tours of the year during the open days.Mr Ferguson thanked all those who visited, adding: ldquoFollowing the success of this event we hope to do another similar event in the future.The m diameter facility is one of the largest dry docks in western Europe and is ideally suited for use in the decommissioning, reactivation of rig, renewables and fabrication sectors. Recent upgrades included a concrete access ramp onto the dry dock floor, and a pumping system that allows the speedy dewatering of the dock.Thursday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Muir of Ord firm aims to step up work
story: AN engineering firm plans ramping up its operating hours to meet demand.Muir of Ord-based Ross-shire Engineering has been tapping the growing market for modular water treatment and chemical dosing plants and pumping stations.An application to extend its hours to seven days a week at their Muir of Ord factory has been lodged with Highland Council. The local authorityrsquos community services environmental health department has no objections subject to noise control measures being implemented.Managing director Allan Dallas said Ross-shire Engineering, which is now part of the Global Energy Group, has increased its workforce by  people in the past  months in Muir of Ord and Cumbernauld. It now employs  people,  of them in the Highlands.He said: ldquoWe have been growing our modular capability and recently sent water treatment plants to Lochmaddy and we have been getting a lot of interest from across Scotland and England.These units are manufactured here in the Highlands and are transported by road and sea to other parts of the UK and abroad.ldquoWe have a highly skilled workforce here in the Highlands but there is a skills gap and to bridge that we have our own graduate apprentice scheme where we train our own young people and we have found that highly successful.He said the application was lodged because the chances are they will need to run a sht pattern to cope with the workload. He said: ldquoWe will work ndashhour shts and will need the capability to work over weekends as well. Itrsquos good news for the workforce and it makes sense for us to keep investing.Thursday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Tractor wheels in motion for tribute to Ullapool crofter
story: A HUGELY successful fundraiser inspired by a Wester Ross teenager may be repeated next year.The memory of Euan MacRae, a crofter who died at the age of  after a battle with bowel cancer, was honoured with a sponsored tractor run organised by friends. It raised pound, for Macmillan cancer services at Raigmore Hospital.Euan, originally from Assynt, was a member of Ullapool Pipe Band and also worked in the village. He died in . Childhood friend James Morrison wanted to pay tribute and organised a sponsored tractor run dubbed TrAtors EUAnite, inspired by Euanrsquos distinctive number plate on his beloved Vauxhall van. More than  tractors took part part with Ullapool Pipe Band welcoming participants over the finish line. Cash raised will help others affected.There are already talks of repeating the tractor run for next year.James Morrison said: ldquoI wanted to get as many wheels turning as possible, in memory of Euan and to raise money and support the efforts of the staff and volunteers. For many weeks during his illness he received chemotherapy at the Macmillan Suite. There he was treated with unfailing care and compassion.A spokeswoman for Macmillan said that a cancer diagnosis can affect much more than health and that patients still need to be treated like people. She said: ldquoBeing told lsquoyou have cancerrsquo can affect so much more than your health ndash it can also affect your family, your job, even your ability to pay the bills. But yoursquore still you. We get that. And, after over  years of helping people through cancer, we get whatrsquos most important: that yoursquore treated as a person, not just a patient.ldquoAt Macmillan we are so thankful to have supporters like James and all those that took part in the Sponsored Tractor Run.Thursday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Young people make their mark
story: Scottish Government ViewpointIN , Scotland came together to celebrate its younger generation.Year of Young Peopleinspired the whole country to look at eight to -year-olds in a more open, positive way: celebrating their achievements, valuing their contributions and giving them an opportunity to influence decision-making.In a year dominated by political uncertainty, young people were the positive force in making change happen. More than  young people were at the heart of it, and planned a calendar of sporting, music and cultural events for all ages to enjoy.A world-first initiative, YoYP was a commitment made by the Scottish Government. Young people worked alongside decision-makers to make sure they were involved in the creation of government policy.This year, they established a Youth Commission which examines mental health services. They will have a greater say in their education with the creation of a Scottish Learner Panel, and hold those in power to account with the launch of the First Ministers Question Time for children and young people.YoYP was delivered in partnership with local and national organisations including schools, youth work services, EventScotland , Young Scot, Scottish Youth Parliament, Children in Scotland and YouthLink Scotland.More than  young ambassadors volunteered their time to challenge the negative stereotypes of their peers. Find out how young people in your area supported YoYP  ndash check out www.yoyp.scot or search #YOYP on social media.Launching YoYP at the start of the year, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "It will give young people a new  and new opportunities and hopefully help to foster a better understanding, co-operation and respect between generations."Thursday  Dec  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
